ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [5th December, 1967], "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1968.". -[The Minister for Finance]

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, the surplus in next year's Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure of $30.28 million, tabled by the Finance Minister for the young Republic, without the loss to any sector of the economy or community, and an overall economic growth of eight per cent in the first nine months of 1967 as compared to a population growth of 2.5 per cent, once again shows a great step forward in the relentless effort to develop our national economy. Sir, this surplus does not fall from the sky. It is the result of careful planning by the Government and the desire to see it through by the Government and the people the employers, the workers and the various communities of the society at large. Sir, our hard work, particularly during the last two years, and the fruitful result that follows give us reason for joy. It has added more confidence to our economy, both internally and internationally. This is an inspiration to us all and we should strengthen it by increasing efforts in the years ahead. For the moment we begin to be complacent, that will be the moment when we begin to dissipate away in this unceasingly turbulent region of the world.

    Sir, two years ago when independence was forced on us and many people were pessimistic about the future, we were not in despair. Very few people then would have the courage to say that such an achievement could be accomplished in so short a period of time. Sir, today we have proved to the world that, though we are a small State, a determined people, equipped with the proper education and training, and under the impetus and dedicated leadership of our present Government, can, I have' every confidence, lead the march to

Column: 547

progress and prosperity and build a non-Communist democratic, socialist nation. Sir, it is particularly heartening to note that not long after our independence came the restoration of diplomatic and trading relations with Indonesia. This, as stated by the Finance Minister, is the most important of the three main reasons for the present buoyancy of the economy. Import and export of many commodities in our trade with Indonesia have not only been restored to the pre-confrontation level in volume, but have also surpassed it. Increase in exports to South Vietnam and the enormous inflow of Hong Kong capital were also the major items contributing to the good performance of our national economy.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the lengthy Budget speech of the Finance Minister was dominated by his concern over the growing unemployment problem and the proposed retrenchment of some 16,000 citizens employed in the British bases within the next three and a half years, and the ways and means he proposed to overcome them. As it is, the Republic faces an increase of about 25,000 employable young people annually. According to the sample Household Survey of the University of Singapore Economic Research Centre, 52,630 were unemployed out of a total of slightly more than half a million employable, that is, about 10 per cent were unemployed, and there is a growing increase of unemployed every year. Sir, this is further aggravated by the impending retrenchment of workers in the British bases and we will probably suffer a drain of about 100,000 economically active people in various categories of labour within the next three and a half years. This will indeed make the situation very acute. But it cannot be denied that given a situation like ours, even the best government in the world cannot solve the problem entirely in a few years. Sir, our Government has at least tried to reduce the problem with a high percentage of success within a bearable limit through expansion and diversity of trade, industrialisation and the opening of new avenues, such as tourism, to create more jobs. The

Column: 548

Government and the citizens themselves have to work very hard for their survival.

    Sir, the Finance Minister has suggested a number of ways to overcome the unemployment problem which, when fully accomplished, will find jobs for about 43,000 people every year for the next few years. But he has never touched on how to assist the farmers to get cheaper fertilizers and cheaper multi-feeds so that they can produce more goods and our people can enjoy cheaper vegetables and livestocks.

    Sir, I take particular interest in the Minister's indication of the tourist trade. As far as I can understand, the Minister has based his calculations in the promotion of the tourist trade chiefly, if not solely, on the building of first-class hotels to create employment for about 9,000 people over the next three and a half years. I do not see how this can induce tourists to visit Singapore, although it cannot be questioned that such ultra modern accommodation does make them feel cosy during their stay. But surely they are not coming here from thousands of miles away just for the purpose of making themselves comfortable in the hotels? Neither do I believe that they are interested in helping us solve our unemployment problem. Sir, to make a success out of the tourist trade, I suggest that the main factor to be considered is how to attract tourists and not how to create jobs out of tourism, and when we have succeeded in this respect, then our services will automatically be in demand, resulting in the creation of direct or indirect employment. Sir, a tourist will ask himself how much he gets out of his spending in the Republic and what he gets out of it, and if he finds that it is not worth his money, not only will he not come again but many of his friends will be encouraged to go elsewhere. Sir, it has always been said that we lack the kind of first-class entertainment, services and facilities found in places like Bangkok, Hong Kong and Japan. Other than their first trip here on business, very few people would want to visit here again. Therefore, some kind of inducement must be added to the

Column: 549

existing ones to make the tourists stay longer and visit here more often. In fact, considerable efforts have been made by the Government and the various business communities to encourage an increase in the number of tourists having their holidays here. But I would say that it is not enough. More efforts and more planning must be put in.

    Sir, all of us are happy to note that the Finance Minister has decided not to increase any tax next year and yet is able to spend more in next year's development. On the whole, the 1968 Budget is a very big New Year gift to the two million people of this young Republic.

    Sir, I fully endorse my support of the motion tabled by the Minister that Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1968.

2.44 p.m.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Sir, I do not wish to dwell at length on the question of economy, because in the past few years we have seen a lot of news on this topic being published in the newspapers. We have also seen how our local merchants have praised our wise Minister for Finance for being able to table such a Budget like this one before us. I must, however, stress that we must pay more attention to the spirit and principle of the Budget than to its details. I would now like to remind the Government that since the expenditure and revenue for next year are balanced, I hope they will make use of the stable economy to pay more attention to the interest of the labourers who constitute a large part of our population, and to implement as quickly as possible the Government's policy in relation to the labouring class in order to reduce in the shortest time possible the gap between the rich and the poor so that we can speedily achieve a democratic, socialist society.

    Sir, I should say the 1968 Budget is satisfactory to all. There are many things which are encouraging to us, one of which is that next year the expenditure

Column: 550

and revenue will balance and there is no increase in taxation, which would have been a burden on the people. Just as the Minister has pointed out, our economy is progressing as it has in the past. There has been an eight per cent increase in national income. This is not only a surprise to many experts, but it also makes us feel proud of our economic achievements because we have achieved quite a lot in the economic field. We can say that ours is a unique case in South-east Asia, and we are enjoying a high standard of living. That goes to show that a country must have a judicious, democratic, socialist leadership and enlightened economic measures before it can achieve social stability, economic prosperity and a rise in the standard of living of the people. I am sure hon. Members will all agree with me that this type of economic policy should not only create prosperity but also achieve stability. So any economic measures adopted by the Government must be based on our platform for nation-building and on our spirit of revolution.

    Sir, allow me to remind the Government that while we, as representatives of the people, are working towards a democratic, socialist, egalitarian and multi-racial society, we must realise the tasks and the responsibilities the people have entrusted to us. I feel that any work in nation-building must aim at the highest achievement and the highest ideal, if we deviate from this path, it will mean that we are deviating from the interests of the people and we will lose their support. Without the base formed by the general masses of the people, we will not be able to carry out our policies and our efforts will be in vain. We must let the people understand that the dynamic force which has generated our present economic prosperity and stability is something which we should understand and which is meaningful. I remember on the 20th of February, 1959, the Deputy Prime Minister gave the reasons why the P.A.P, had received the support of the people. He said that most of the people of Singapore were labourers and were

Column: 551

being exploited. They supported our aim for an equal and just society and our policies for equal opportunities in employment and other fields and they wanted to have a better standard of living. The merchants also supported us because of our integrity and anti-corruption campaigns and other effective administrative measures. They supported an honest and clean government which would be conducive to their economic interests so that they could live in peace. The present Minister for Finance, namely, Dr Goh Keng Swee, at that time said that the economic policy of the P.A.P. was mainly aimed at getting the best things for the majority of our people, namely, security and prosperity.

    Sir, I am saying all this in order to show the economic challenge before us so that we may analyse seriously our work in the past year. Everybody knows that the P.A.P. Government ever since it came to power has carried out revolutionary work in all fields, and everybody knows our achievements. What we have been able to achieve has enabled to create a stable society and a prosperous economy and this clearly shows the efficiency of our Government. I would like to avail myself of this opportunity today to remind the Government to redouble its efforts in its tasks, fired by its revolutionary spirit, as it has been in the past, and serve this country and implement its economic policies in order to bring equality to all sections of the people: in other words, to close the gap between the rich and the poor. As everybody can see, Singapore is prosperous and very progressive. But we should not look only at the optimistic side of the picture and neglect the other side of it. The other side is one of the platforms of the P.A.P.'s manifesto, i.e., to bridge the gap between the rich and the poor, and to establish a non-Communist, democratic, socialist, fair and just society where there is no exploitation of man by man.

    I have said all this in order that all the people concerned can pay more attention to this so as to bring to realisation all that we have hoped for. We should also allow our younger generation

Column: 552

to understand our problems and our tasks. We all know that most of the consumers are in the middle and lower income groups. These consumers are purchasers. They must have a good standard of living before they can spend more. Although the average income of the workers has improved somewhat more than before, generally speaking, however, the degree of improvement is very small. Although the market for consumer goods is quite active, most of the goods are purchased on hire purchase terms. Many consumers, after acquiring such consumer goods on an instalment basis, later find themselves unable to pay the whole amount due. So they get into difficulties because of lack of money. From these instances, we can see clearly that though one side of the picture represents our nation as prosperous, on the other side of it, however, there are still the workers whose purchasing power is limited.

    Another point I would like to suggest is that when we talk about individual income, the accumulative income of an individual may increase his purchasing power, but there are instances where the method of taxation may not channel capital into productive fields. The people are generally paying taxes, but the rich are still able to evade paying what they should pay. So this has brought about a greater difference between the rich and the poor and a certain amount of economic imbalance in society, with the result that there may not be an equal enjoyment of the services provided by the country. The poor will be struggling forever in dire poverty; the rich will be richer; and therefore the line between the rich and the poor will be more marked.

    There is an outstanding problem with regard to urban renewal. Everybody wants to look forward to a better future, but the upheavals caused by urban renewal cannot escape our attention. Urban renewal schemes should achieve social progress and not cause any exploitation of the people. They should not cause the people any inconvenience. But we have seen that many people have been forcibly removed as a result

Column: 553

of urban renewal schemes. These people - especially the hawkers and small merchants - have suffered quite a lot economically as a result of urban renewal schemes. Although we have allotted them shops, they normally fight shy of taking them up because of the high rentals. They just admire the shops without daring to rent them. Yet we are encouraging the capitalists to take part in our urban renewal schemes by giving them more favourable terms. Of course, nobody can accuse us of not encouraging them to invest in order to increase our economic prosperity. We are giving them a lot of encouragement and favourable terms. For instance, we grant them tax exemption for a number of years, good sites for development, better attention and facilities. From this glaring example, the people are given the impression that we are granting better facilities to the rich who are availing themselves of Government assistance to achieve their own purposes. On the other hand, the small merchants and hawkers have more or less to close shop after they have been forcibly evicted. This situation can he described as an abnormal development. In other words, we are helping the rich and doing nothing for the poor. Thus, this problem is not being looked into properly by the Government.

    Therefore, I would like to express the hope that our Government will thoroughly carry out the objectives in their manifesto in a revolutionary spirit in order to bring about a democratic, non-Communist socialist society and to redress the balance between the poor and the rich. I hope the Government can put forward suggestions to achieve this.

    The Government's policy with regard to the encouragement of foreign investments should also take account of the interest of the small merchants and hawkers so that there can be equal development among all sections of our population. I am of the view that the Government should set up a loan organisation, for instance, to help taxi-drivers.

Column: 554

We know that their taxis are mostly on loan or on hire, and some of them purchase them on hire purchase terms at very high interest. So their monthly expenses are very heavy. In addition, they have to maintain their families. Very often, they cannot continue to pay their instalments half-way and their vehicles are taken back by the sellers. So this loan organisation can in a way help to solve part of the problems of the taxi-drivers.

    The small merchants who are evicted as a result of urban renewal should also be helped by the Government to resettle in new shops by a scheme of service. The Government should help to re-establish their businesses through some form of loans, because we know that even the large commercial firms have to depend on larger financial organisations to back them up. So this is a factor that will affect our economic prosperity.

    Secondly, I think the Government can set up a corporation to enable the people to invest in it, to encourage them to buy shares of various firms and industries. Thus the investors will not be confined to just a small group of people. This will help the masses to take part in investment schemes and become shareholders. If there are more investors, there will be more funds to replenish our financial resources and to help carry out the Government's economic policies. It is also in keeping with the Government's economic plans and the nature of our economy so that our national wealth can be more equally distributed among our people. This will help them to achieve a better and equal socialist society earlier.

    I have given my suggestions. At the same time, I would also like to express my support for the many good points in the Budget Statement of the Minister for Finance.

3.11 p.m.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, it would indeed be difficult to find a newly independent and developing nation, particularly in

Column: 555

this part of the world, whose Budget Estimates show a surplus and whose revenue exceeds its expenditure. It is a truism to say that every newly independent and developing nation inevitably finds it necessary to raise income tax, import tax, property tax and various taxes of one kind or another or to obtain loans from foreign countries or, if not, to sell one of the islands in its territory in order to finance its national expenditure. There was a time during the Lim Yew Hock regime when the Singapore Government found it necessary to sell Christmas Island in order to get money to overcome the deficit in the national Budget.

    However, Singapore, ever since it came under the P.A.P. rule, has steadily progressed in prosperity. Its social services have improved; its housing problems which posed a major problem at one time have now been successfully overcome; every child born is assured of a place in school, no matter whether he stays far or near; industrial disputes between employers and employees are decreasing in number. All these achievements are due to the dedication, sincerity and hard work of the leaders as well as to their correct leadership in striving towards the goal of progress and prosperity and harmony among its multi-racial citizens. Moreover, the Minister for Finance is an acknowledged expert in economics. That is why Singapore today can justly be proud of the successes it has achieved.

    It is usual, every time the Minister for Finance presents the Budget Estimates, for every sector of the public, from the businessman to the worker, to become apprehensive and wonder whether there will be any increases in taxes. But this time the public were much relieved when it was announced that there were to be no increases in taxes for the coming year. If there are those who are somewhat worried - the number is not big - it is because of the devaluation of the Pound Sterling. But I believe that they too will be relieved to know that the economy of Singapore is not only

Column: 556

stable but improving from time to time, as has been stated by the Minister in his policy speech on the Budget for 1968.

    One of the facts he gave was that the use of granite continues to increase due to building construction - construction of new roads and repair of old roads - an increase of two and a half times. Another economic indicator, which the Minister found interesting to watch, was the increase in the number of motorcycles and scooters registered. Five years ago, the average was 548 per month, but for the last three months the average was 1,258. So too is it the case with the construction of factories, etc.

    However, Mr Speaker, Sir, the examples mentioned just now are as yet no cause for satisfaction to me. The increase in the use of granite to build new roads - to nearly 130,000 cubic yards per month - is of little benefit to Kampong Kembangan Constituency. To date, the roads in Kampong Kembangan are still full of pot-holes and unfit not only for vehicular traffic but also for pedestrians. The fact is that requests and appeals have incessantly and repeatedly been made to the Ministry, but unfortunately all to no avail. So today you find that about 80 per cent of the roads in Kampong Kembangan are still in a sorry state. Moreover, during the present rainy season, with Christmas coming soon, to be followed by Han Raya Puasa and Chinese New Year, you can be sure that the residents of Kampong Kembangan, who are of various races and religions, will be observing these days with an air of despondency and gloom, even though taxes are not raised.

    The Minister for Finance was elated to note the increase in the number of motor-cycles and scooters registered in the past three months, an indication that skilled artisans and white-collar workers are also benefiting from our economic expansion. I am, however, sad when I think of the number of car-owners who have found it necessary to sell their cars because of the increase last December in the cost of petrol, car tax, and driving licence fees. Furthermore, they have to

Column: 557

pay for parking in the city, to the extent that car-owners, even if they are flat dwellers, have to pay to park near their homes.

    These are some of the reasons for the increase in the number of motorcycles and scooters registered, rather than that the increase is due to economic expansion. Car owners have to economise, and the simplest and cheapest way is to sell their cars and buy motor-cycles and scooters instead.

    Sir, with regard to the increase in the number of new factories, admittedly this is good because it provides jobs for the unemployed. But my complaint is that a number of these factories are built in residential areas, such as Kampong Kembangan. My constituency is a residential area, but industries such as sawmills, iron foundries, etc, are fast growing in number, like mushrooms after a heavy rain. All this affects the peace and tranquillity of the residents in my constituency. Quite often the power supply is disrupted on account of the heavy machinery, and the noise emanating therefrom disturbs the tranquillity of the neighbourhood and is another nuisance to the children who wish to study their lessons at home. Roads and drains are damaged. Far from being regularly maintained and repaired, these roads and drains are now subjected to constant use by heavy vehicles which pass to and from the factories, causing even greater damage.

    Lastly, although the figures and indications which point to our economic development are interesting, as stated by the Minister for Finance, nevertheless I, for one, am still not convinced that the people of Singapore will not experience increased taxation in 1968. In the first place, if the Minister is unable to anticipate the number of Government officers going into retirement as evidenced in the Supplementary Estimates for 1967, which was debated last Monday, I do not see how he is able to anticipate that the collection of revenue will exceed expenditure for

Column: 558

1968. In the second place, the Minister himself stated that he expected another set of Supplementary Estimates for next year. Whereas the surplus for 1968 is only to the tune of $0.3 million, the Supplementary Estimates for 1967 was for more than $5 million. Thus, the Budget Estimates for 1968 are at best vague. It is not as yet certain that the people of Singapore will not experience tax increases in the coming year.

3.23 p.m.

    Mr Lim Soo Peng (Havelock): Mr Speaker, Sir, much praise has been given to the Budget speech of the Finance Minister - by the ordinary man in the street, by bankers, industrialists, traders,, and merchants. The speakers before me have also praised him, and I am sure the speakers after me too, will be resounding these praises, if I were to add even more praise, I am afraid the Finance Minister might not be able to bear the burden. And so, if I do not join in the chorus, then I think it does not deserve praise.

    The Budget speech on the financial policy of the Government for the year 1968 can be divided broadly into three parts. Firstly, the Finance Minister surveys the progress for the year; secondly, he analyses the problems of the ensuing year; and, thirdly, he tells us what he proposes to do with it. As I sat listening to his survey, I could not help feeling very proud of being a Singapore citizen. Mr Speaker, Sir, I assure you it was not on account of the language of the Finance Minister, whose language was indeed restrained and sober. My pride swelled from the facts the Minister reeled out one after another. Everything was up - trade was up, not only in value but even more so in volume, and by a staggering 15 per cent.

    According to a very recent Colombo Plan report quoted in the local Press, only two countries in Asia had an increase in their share of the world trade. These are Singapore and South Korea, bearing in mind that we flourish (to use the words of the Finance

Column: 559

Minister) entirely on skill and expertise. The distinction in trade is something to warm all our hearts. The number of ships using our harbour has gone up, and so has the tonnage. Bank deposits are up. So has building construction gone up - both public and private. There was even a short shortage of cement. Receipts from tourism are up, and there is a grave shortage of hotels which we are trying very hard to remedy. Manufacturing output has gone up, and industrial investment is also up, so much so that the Economic Development Board has to have a crash programme in factory construction.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our achievements for the year have really been impressive and satisfying. But what is more gratifying is that not only have we kept up with economic development which began in 1959, but we have also distributed the uses of our increasing wealth in a more just and equitable manner. Since 1959, in spite of rapid population increases, the per capita income has risen from about $1,200 to about $1,700, or by about 42 per cent. At this figure we certainly have a per capita income exceeded only perhaps by Japan in Asia. This alone will mean very little to the common man if he does not get an increasing share of the use of the increased wealth. As the Minister has observed - and on which I can personally testify - not only has the number of cars but also the number of motor-cycles and scooters has gone up very rapidly. All the factories in Jurong that I know of provide substantial parking lots for motor-cycles and scooters of the ordinary worker.

    If further proof of a better life for the ordinary worker is required, one need go no further than to any of the vast subsidised public housing estates and observe the living conditions there. One will see radio and television sets in nearly every home. One will see the car parks full of cars, motor-cycles and scooters. The only thing that one perhaps will not see is a boy or girl of school-going age not in school.

Column: 560



    Another very satisfying matter is the continued improvement in the industrial relations climate in Singapore. This is no doubt one of the important factors in our economic progress during the year. According to figures published by the Labour Ministry, man-days lost on account of strikes dropped from a peak of 411,000 in 1961 to 44,000 in 1966. Figures for this year are not yet available. But from what we know, except for the Hume Industries strike, there does not seem to be any major work stoppages. The better industrial relations climate today may be attributable to a reorientation of basic thinking between both management and labour circles. There has been a marked willingness on both sides to place national interests, and therefore of the general good, before any other interests, and there has developed a new mood where both sides are increasingly anxious to sit down and reason rather than to fight it out. This is especially so in the Jurong industrial complex, it is here, I think, that the workers deserve a special compliment; not only have they and their leaders, with rare exceptions, shown a remarkable degree of responsibility in industrial relations, but they have also widened their activities into the social, cultural and recreational fields. In these activities, I am glad to note that the management has willingly co-operated by donating funds. If the good work is sustained, I am confident that before long Jurong's leisure hours will be as vigorous as during working hours. The Economic Development Board also deserve a compliment. I have heard from both labour and management leaders that had it not been for the understanding and support of the Board, progress would have been very much less.

    Turning now to the problems of the coming year, we find that in spite of the advances we have made, unemployment will still be a threat to the core of our social fabric. As the Finance Minister has rightly pointed out, if Singapore has not done so much as it did in stimulating economic growth, the situation would have been much worse.

Column: 561

But now with Britain's military withdrawal, our problem - again to quote the Finance Minister - has been severely aggravated. According to him, by 1971, 16,000 people will be retrenched by the British. We have already 52,000 unemployed and every year we have 25,000 people coming out of schools looking for jobs. Thus if we are to solve our unemployment problem completely, the Finance Minister tells us, we have to create 43,000 jobs every year for the next three years. This is indeed a gigantic task calling for prodigious efforts. In industry, figures, of course, vary from factory to factory. It takes generally at least $3,000 to create one job. If we are to create 43,000 jobs in industry, we will need $1,290 million in investment every year. If we compare this figure with our gross national product estimated for 1966, at about $3,200 million, we will see the magnitude of our task. In other words, the gross capital formation will have to be more than one-third of our gross national product.
